title: Railway Safety Inquiry Concludes After Baghmati Express Accident
news:
The Commissioner of Railway Safety (CRS) for the Southern Circle, A.M. Choudhary, has concluded his inquiry into the Baghmati Express train accident that occurred in Tiruvallur district, Tamil Nadu. The accident involved the Mysuru-Darbhanga train colliding with a stationary goods wagon at Kavaraipettai, resulting in injuries to 20 passengers and a fire in two bogies.

The inquiry, which spanned two days (October 16-17), involved questioning around 30 railway staff, including the locomotive pilot, assistant locomotive pilot, station masters, and section controllers. Although the public was invited to participate, no outsiders contributed to the inquiry. 

Prior to the formal questioning, Mr. Choudhary visited the accident site on October 15 and initiated a preliminary round of questioning. The final inquiry took place at the Chennai Divisional Railway Manager's office. The CRS's findings are expected to shed light on the cause of the accident and may lead to recommendations for safety improvements.

title: India's National Green Tribunal Orders Coastal Zone Map Revision and Eco-Sensitive Area Verification
news:
The Southern Bench of the National Green Tribunal (NGT) has directed the Tamil Nadu State Coastal Zone Management Authority (SCZMA) to revise incomplete coastal zone maps and verify ecologically sensitive areas. This decision follows a case filed by fisherman Jesu Rathinam, who highlighted the lack of crucial information in the draft Coastal Zone Management Plan (CZMP).

The NGT has ordered the SCZMA and the National Centre for Sustainable Coastal Management to verify the designated ecologically sensitive areas, as previously outlined by the Madras High Court and the NGT. This verification process must include input from coastal district collectors and consider the feedback of stakeholders.

The draft CZMP is mandated to include essential components like fishing zones, breeding grounds, communal properties of fishermen, and housing plans for coastal communities.  The NGT emphasized the need to ensure that the final maps adequately address these requirements and leave no room for public complaints.

The NGT has also instructed the SCZMA to conduct ground truthing to investigate potential omissions or discrepancies in the maps. This will help protect coastal integrity and address ecological and human concerns.

The public hearing, originally scheduled for August 2023, has been postponed until the maps are revised and verified. The NGT has stated that a new hearing date will be announced following legal procedures and after stakeholders have been given time to review the updated maps and provide their feedback.

title: Delhi, UP Police Arrest Second Shooter in Gym Owner Murder
news:
Police forces from Delhi and Uttar Pradesh have jointly arrested a second shooter, Yogesh alias Raju, in connection with the murder of a gym owner in Greater Kailash 1, New Delhi. The arrest comes just a week after the arrest of his associate, Madhur alias Ayaan, in an encounter in Narela.

The incident, believed to be a gang-related crime, occurred on September 12th when Nadir Shah, a known criminal involved in robbery and attempted murder cases, was shot dead outside his gym.  

Raju, a resident of Badaun in Uttar Pradesh, is reportedly a member of the Lawrence Bishnoi and Hashim Baba gangs. He was apprehended in Mathura after a shootout with police, sustaining a gunshot injury to his left leg. 

During the arrest, authorities recovered a .32 bore pistol with seven live cartridges, three empty shells, and a motorcycle without a registration plate. 

Raju is facing multiple criminal charges in Badaun and Kasganj districts of Uttar Pradesh, as well as in Delhi.

title: Delhi BJP Reconsiders Subsidies Ahead of Assembly Polls
news:
With the Delhi Assembly elections looming in early 2025, the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) is facing pressure to re-evaluate its stance on subsidies. The party, which last held power in the national capital in 1998, is currently engaged in intensive discussions to solidify its election strategy. 

Local BJP leaders have expressed concern that the party's previous opposition to subsidies, dubbed "revdi culture," could cost them votes. They argue that the residents of Delhi have become accustomed to the subsidized services provided by the incumbent Aam Aadmi Party (AAP) government, including electricity, water, and free bus rides for women.

The BJP's campaign currently focuses on highlighting the AAP government's perceived failures and promoting a "double-engine government" – a unified ruling party at both the national and state levels. However, party sources believe that to effectively compete with the AAP, the BJP must address the issue of subsidies, potentially offering similar benefits to gain voter support.

The 2020 and 2015 Assembly elections saw the BJP fail to secure a majority, and the party is determined to improve its performance in the upcoming election.  While acknowledging that the BJP will likely win seats in the double-digits, party strategists believe that to achieve a majority, they need to reassure voters that their subsidies will remain under a BJP-led government.

title: AAP Courts Valmiki Community on Jayanti
news:
On the occasion of Valmiki Jayanti, Aam Aadmi Party (AAP) leader Arvind Kejriwal highlighted his party's contributions to the Valmiki community in Delhi. He emphasized that AAP appointed the city's first Minister and Deputy Speaker from the community, referring to Rakhi Birla. 

Kejriwal also touted AAP's efforts in the Municipal Corporation of Delhi (MCD), stating that thousands of ad-hoc sanitation workers have been given permanent jobs under their tenure. He highlighted the recent regularization of over 600 sanitation workers and promised continued efforts in this regard. 

He added that AAP's governance in the MCD has ensured sanitation workers receive their salaries within the first week of each month, enabling them to lead a dignified life. This, he stated, is a significant improvement from the previous situation where workers faced months-long delays in receiving their wages.

Meanwhile, BJP leaders visited the Valmiki Temple in Delhi and paid tribute to the scholar. They participated in a chariot procession starting from Red Fort, highlighting Valmiki's contributions to Sanskrit literature and his promotion of unity and peace through his teachings.

title: Congress Launches Campaign Vehicles in Delhi to Gather Public Opinion Ahead of Election
news:
The Delhi Pradesh Congress Committee has launched seven mobile vans to collect suggestions for their upcoming Delhi Assembly election manifesto. This initiative, dubbed "Dilliwalon Aao—Dilli Chalao," aims to engage directly with citizens. 

The vans will travel across the city, offering residents a platform to share their ideas and priorities for the Capital. People can also submit suggestions online or via phone.

Congress Delhi chief Devender Yadav, who launched the campaign, criticized the Aam Aadmi Party (AAP) for its alleged "corruption and incompetence" during its 10-year rule. He stated that the Congress is committed to providing an "able and stable" government in the city.

This move comes as the Congress seeks to regain their foothold in Delhi after losing the past two Assembly elections. The party is contesting the upcoming election independently, after having allied with the AAP in the recent Lok Sabha elections.

title: Union Minister's Kin Accused of Cheating in Election Ticket Scam
news:
The brother, sister, and son of Union Minister Pralhad Joshi have been booked by the Basaveshwaranagar police in Bengaluru for allegedly cheating a couple out of crores of rupees by promising them a ticket to contest the 2024 Lok Sabha elections. 

The complainants, Sunitha Chauvan and her husband, former JD(S) MLA Devanand Phool Singh Chauhan, allege that they were approached by an acquaintance, Shekhar Nayak, who claimed to have connections with Gopal Joshi, the Minister's brother. Nayak allegedly promised them a ticket in exchange for a payment of ₹5 crore. 

The couple met with Gopal Joshi in March 2024 and were later introduced to the Minister himself. Gopal Joshi reportedly claimed that Prahlad Joshi had strong connections with top leaders in the central government, including Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Union Home Minister Amit Shah. 

The Chauhans initially refused the offer but later agreed to pay ₹25 lakh after being pressured by Gopal Joshi. They handed the money over to Vijayalakshmi Joshi, the Minister's sister, in the presence of Gopal Joshi. 

Despite paying the money, the couple did not receive the promised ticket. When they confronted Gopal Joshi, he allegedly refused to return the money, claiming it was tied to a pending government project. He later requested an additional ₹1.75 crore, promising a refund after the project was approved. The Chauhans paid this amount as well, but it was never returned. 

The complaint also alleges that Vijayalakshmi Joshi physically assaulted Sunitha Chauvan and made derogatory comments about their caste.  

Based on the complaint, the police have registered an FIR against the trio for cheating, criminal breach of trust, criminal conspiracy, and offenses under the SC and ST (Prevention of Atrocities) Act.

title: Kerala High Court Quashes POCSO Case Against Principal and Teacher
news:
The Kerala High Court has dismissed a criminal case filed under the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act against a school principal and teacher in Kochi. The case was brought against them for failing to report a student's complaint of sexual abuse to the police immediately. 

The court ruled that while it is mandatory to report such crimes to the police within 24 hours, reporting the incident the following day does not necessarily constitute a failure to report. In this case, the principal and teacher were informed of the crime on November 17, 2022, and they alerted the police the next day. The court found no evidence of intentional omission on their part in reporting the crime.

title: Indian Supreme Court Justice Raises Concerns About Citizenship Act Incentivizing Illegal Immigration
news:
On October 17, 2024, Justice J.B. Pardiwala, the sole dissenting judge on the Supreme Court’s Constitution Bench, argued that Section 6A of the Citizenship Act of 1955 effectively encourages undocumented immigrants from Bangladesh to remain in Assam indefinitely.  

Justice Pardiwala highlighted a key issue:  the requirement for migrants to be officially declared foreigners before they can register for citizenship.  This detection process can only be initiated by the state, and according to Justice Pardiwala, Section 6A lacks any provision for self-declaration or voluntary identification as a foreigner.  

This situation, according to Justice Pardiwala,  effectively allows undocumented immigrants to remain in Assam indefinitely, with no time limit for the state to detect them. They are also eligible to vote until their status is officially declared, and thus enjoy the benefits of de facto citizenship.  He further criticized the arbitrary nature of the 10-year removal from electoral rolls following detection, arguing it contradicts the stated goal of expedited detection, deportation, and eventual citizenship. 

In his dissent, Justice Pardiwala concluded that Section 6A and its associated benefits should not be extended to immigrants in Assam from the date of this judgement.

title: Tamil Nadu Allocates ₹209.20 Crore for Rural Housing Scheme
news:
The Tamil Nadu government has approved ₹209.20 crore for the implementation of the Pradhan Mantri Awaas Yojana - Gramin (PMAY-G) in rural areas during the 2024-25 fiscal year. This allocation includes a 60% central share of ₹125.52 crore and a 40% state share of ₹83.68 crore, constituting the first tranche of the initial installment, including administration funds.

The Rural Development and Panchayat Raj Department issued the orders for this allocation. The Union Ministry of Rural Development had approved the PMAY-G for a further five years, from 2024-25 to 2028-29, with the goal of constructing "two crore more houses". Tamil Nadu's target for 2024-25 was set at 68,569 houses, with beneficiaries selected from the existing Awaas-Plus database from 2018.

The Indian government has fixed a unit cost of ₹1.20 lakh per house, with the cost and administration funds to be shared between the Union and State governments in a 60:40 ratio. This expenditure will be presented to the legislature in the Supplementary Estimates for 2024-25.

title: Is Bengaluru Worth the Sacrifice? Techie Weighs European Life vs. Indian Paycheck
news:
A tech professional earning nearly ₹80 lakh annually in Europe is considering a move to Bengaluru for a job offering ₹50 lakh.  While attracted by India's larger market and better purchasing power, the techie is hesitant due to concerns about quality of life. 

The Reddit post sparked a debate, with most commenters advising against the move.  They cite concerns including:

* **Work-Life Balance:**  Europe's stricter labor laws offer more job security and less pressure compared to India's often demanding work culture.
* **Quality of Life:**  Issues like air and water pollution, corruption, and challenges in healthcare and government services were cited as deterrents.
* **Leave Policies:**  Extended leave is more readily available in Europe, while securing even a short break in India can be difficult.

While some acknowledged that personal circumstances could influence the decision, the majority emphasized the benefits of stability, work-life balance, and overall quality of life in Europe over Bengaluru.

title: Congress MLA Booked for Allegedly Abusing Lord Shiva in Video
news:
Babu Singh Jandel, a two-time Congress MLA from Madhya Pradesh's Sheopur, has been booked after a video purportedly showing him using abusive language against Lord Shiva went viral.  The video, which has sparked outrage, prompted the Madhya Pradesh BJP to launch an attack on the Congress ahead of the upcoming bypoll in the Vijaypur Assembly constituency. 

Two complaints were filed against Jandel, resulting in an FIR being registered at the Kotwali police station.  The FIR includes charges under sections 196, 223, 299, and 302 of the Bharatiya Nyay Sanhita (Indian Penal Code). 

Jandel maintains the video is edited, while the BJP claims the incident is part of the Congress's "nefarious agenda to wipe out Sanatan from the country," urging the party to take action against their MLA. 

The bypoll in Vijaypur, along with the Budhni Assembly seat, is scheduled for November 20th. The bypoll in Vijaypur was necessitated after Ramniwas Rawat, a six-term Congress MLA, joined the BJP and resigned from his seat.

title: Andhra Pradesh Intermediate Students Have Until November 11th to Pay Exam Fees
news:
Intermediate students in Andhra Pradesh have until November 11th to pay their examination fees without incurring a fine. This deadline was announced by Board of Intermediate Education (BIE) Secretary Kritika Shukla. 

Students can pay their fees with a fine of ₹1,000 between November 12th and November 20th, 2024. After this date, no further extensions will be granted.

The announcement also applies to students who are seeking attendance exemption online, who must submit their applications and pay a fee of ₹1,500 by November 15th.  A penalty fee of ₹500 will be levied for applications submitted after November 15th, with a final deadline of November 30th.

This information is crucial for Intermediate students in Andhra Pradesh who are preparing for the upcoming public examinations scheduled for March 2025.

title: Change Attitude, Help Road Accident Victims: Police Commissioner's Appeal
news:
Kalaburagi, India -  Police Commissioner Sharanappa S.D. has urged citizens to change their attitude and assist road accident victims, highlighting the legal protection offered to good Samaritans under the Supreme Court's landmark ruling. Speaking at the World Trauma Day event at United Hospital on Thursday, he emphasized the importance of acting swiftly to save lives, stating, "Don't fear odds, step forward to help accident victims." 

The "good Samaritan law" ensures those who transport accident victims to the nearest hospital within the "golden hour" are protected from legal repercussions.  Commissioner Sharanappa emphasized the devastating impact of road accidents, not only claiming lives but also leaving survivors with physical and psychological trauma. 

India faces a serious road safety crisis, with the country recording 10-12% of the world's road accident fatalities. According to a recent survey, India holds the highest number of road accident fatalities globally, with an estimated 460 deaths daily.  Commissioner Sharanappa pointed out the alarming trend of young people violating traffic rules, contributing significantly to the accident rate. 

He called for collaborative efforts between citizens, the road transportation department, and traffic officials to implement road safety awareness programs and address the issue effectively. "The common people must understand that the traffic rules are imposed to ensure public safety and not to harass people," he reiterated.

title: Tamil Nadu Deputy Chief Minister Orders Swift Removal of Water Hyacinths
news:
Chennai, India - Tamil Nadu Deputy Chief Minister Udhayanidhi Stalin ordered the immediate removal of water hyacinths from a waterbody in S. Kolathur after residents raised concerns during his visit on October 15. The Deputy Chief Minister, who has been overseeing rain relief efforts in Chennai, personally inspected the area and responded to the residents' request. 

Following his instructions, officials from the Water Resources Department used specialized machinery to clear the water hyacinths. Mr. Stalin returned to the site on October 15 evening and the following afternoon to ensure the completion of the removal operation.  The official release stated that residents expressed gratitude for the swift resolution of the issue.

title: Kolkata Junior Doctors Push for Change Amidst Hunger Strike
news:
Protesting junior doctors in Kolkata, India, have escalated their campaign for improved working conditions and safety by collecting signatures from the public. This comes as the doctors’ hunger strike, which began on October 5th, continues, with several doctors hospitalized due to deteriorating health.

The movement, spearheaded by the West Bengal Junior Doctors Front, aims to address a range of concerns, including the murder of a doctor at R. G. Kar Hospital on August 9th. The group demands the removal of State Health Secretary N S Nigam, increased security measures, and a fixed timeline for addressing their concerns. 

Aniket Mahato, a prominent figure in the movement, was recently hospitalized due to the hunger strike. Upon his release, he urged the Chief Minister, Mamata Banerjee, to intervene and expedite the investigation into the murdered doctor’s case.

While the West Bengal government claims to be working on solutions, the doctors remain unsatisfied by the lack of concrete action. The government's proposed referral system is seen as a pilot project, lacking a fixed timeline for implementation.

The protests have garnered public support, with demonstrations outside the office of the Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) demanding a swift investigation into the murder case. 

This ongoing crisis underscores the need for immediate action to address the safety concerns of junior doctors and ensure a safe working environment in state-run hospitals.

title: Valmiki Statue to be Erected at Mysuru DC Office
news:
Mysuru, Karnataka: A statue of the renowned poet and saint Maharishi Valmiki will be erected on the premises of the deputy commissioner's office in Mysuru. The foundation stone for the project was laid on Thursday, October 17th, coinciding with Valmiki Jayanti. 

The project, estimated to cost ₹1.50 crore, was announced by Minister in charge of Mysuru district, H.C. Mahadevappa. The statue is expected to be unveiled during the next Valmiki Jayanti celebrations.  

The unveiling of the statue will be accompanied by the unveiling of another statue, honoring former Chief Minister D. Devaraj Urs, on the same premises. 

The demand for a Valmiki statue had been pending for a significant period. The ground-breaking ceremony on Valmiki Jayanti marks the fulfillment of this long-standing request.

title: No Urea-DAP Shortage in Uttar Pradesh, Claims Agriculture Department
news:
The Uttar Pradesh Agriculture Department has assured the public that there will be no shortage of urea and DAP fertilizers in the state, despite rising demand for the upcoming Rabi season. According to a recent report from the Agriculture Directorate, adequate stocks of urea, DAP, NPK, MOP, and SSP are available.

To prevent black marketing, the department has increased vigilance at state borders, particularly in districts bordering Nepal and neighboring states. 

The report states that sufficient fertilizer quotas are available compared to the set targets. For example, 28.75 lakh tonnes of urea were available as of October 16th, against a target of 39 lakh tonnes for the entire Rabi season. 

The department is also emphasizing the balanced use of urea and DAP to ensure efficient fertilizer utilization. 

While acknowledging that some districts may experience temporary shortages due to farmers stocking up early, the department maintains that there is no overall shortage.  

The report also highlights the department's efforts to combat black marketing through increased surveillance at border areas, especially in districts bordering Nepal and neighboring states, where fertilizer consumption has historically been higher than other areas.

title: Elephant Eats Rice and Plastic in Coimbatore
news:
A wild elephant caused a stir in Semmedu, near Coimbatore, on Wednesday night, after it raided a local grocery store and consumed both rice and the plastic bag it was packaged in. The elephant, one of two known to frequent the area, pulled a bag of rice from the store and fed on it. Videos of the incident circulated widely on social media. 

This incident has led to increased concern among residents and farmers, who have recently protested outside the Forest Department staff quarters due to damage caused by the elephants. In response, the Forest Department has deployed three teams to conduct night patrols in the area.

title: Eight Crocodiles Escape After Lorry Overturns in Telangana
news:
A lorry transporting eight crocodiles from Patna, Bihar, to Bengaluru, Karnataka, overturned in Telangana on Thursday, October 17, 2024. The incident occurred near Mondigutta forest check-post after the lorry crashed into an electric transmission pole. 

During the accident, two crocodiles escaped from their container. Nirmal police, with the assistance of the Forest department, successfully captured the escaped reptiles and loaded them into another vehicle along with the remaining crocodiles. All eight crocodiles were transported to their destination in Bengaluru safely.

The driver, Abdul Mannan Mandal, was booked under Section 281 of the BNS Act by the Mamada Police of Nirmal for reckless driving.  Police investigation revealed the driver was drowsy and did not have a co-driver. 

The crocodiles were being transported legally from Sanjay Gandhi Biological Park in Patna to Bannerghatta Biological Park in Bengaluru.

title: Kidney Transplant Breakthrough: Woman with Vascular Blockage Receives Life-Saving Surgery
news:
A 49-year-old woman with kidney failure and significant vascular blockages underwent a successful kidney transplant at a private hospital in Chennai, India. The procedure was unique due to the connection of the donor kidney's arteries directly to the recipient's aorta, the largest artery in the body. This approach was necessary because of the patient's pre-existing vascular blockages, which typically make transplant surgery too risky.

Traditionally, kidney transplants connect the donor kidney's arteries to the recipient's iliac vessels. However, patients with severe arterial blockages were previously considered unfit for transplantation. This breakthrough procedure allows a larger pool of patients with kidney failure to receive life-saving treatment.

The surgical team at SIMS Institute of Urology and Renal Transplantation successfully connected the arteries, enabling the patient to receive a healthy kidney. One year after the transplant, the patient is reported to have excellent renal function and overall health. This successful case marks a significant advancement in kidney transplantation, offering hope to patients with vascular blockages who were previously excluded from this life-saving procedure.

title: Congress Nominates Ravindra Chavan for Nanded Bypoll, Accuses Mahayuti of Disrespecting Shivaji Maharaj's Legacy
news:
The Congress has announced Ravindra Chavan, son of the late Vasantrao Chavan, as their candidate for the Nanded Lok Sabha by-election scheduled for November 20th. The seat became vacant following the death of Vasantrao Chavan in August. 

Meanwhile, the Congress has accused the ruling Mahayuti government of disrespecting the legacy of Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj, a prominent historical figure in India. They cite the collapse of a Shivaji Maharaj statue in Sindhudurg and the abandonment of a planned statue in the Arabian Sea as evidence of the government's neglect. 

The Congress further criticized the Mahayuti for removing a Shivaji Maharaj statue from its place outside Parliament, claiming the government is trying to spite the people of Maharashtra following their electoral defeat in June. They warn that those who disrespect Maharashtra's history and culture will face consequences in the upcoming elections.

title: BJP Demands Postponement of UP By-elections Due to Kartik Purnima
news:
The Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) has requested the Election Commission to postpone the upcoming by-elections in nine Uttar Pradesh assembly constituencies, scheduled for November 13th. The party fears that the Kartik Purnima festival, which falls on November 15th, will significantly impact voter turnout. 

A large number of people, particularly in the regions of Kundarki, Mirapur, Ghaziabad, and Prayagraj, traditionally travel for religious ceremonies and fairs associated with Kartik Purnima, starting several days before the actual festival. The BJP argues that this exodus would lead to a substantial decrease in voter participation, potentially undermining the integrity of the election.

The BJP delegation, which met with the Additional Chief Electoral Officer Chandrashekhar, believes postponing the elections to November 20th would ensure a higher voter turnout and allow for a more representative electoral process. The party emphasizes the Election Commission's own desire for 100% voter participation and argues that the proposed postponement would be conducive to achieving this goal.

title: Aspiring Architects and Planners Encouraged to Embrace Self-Belief and Conviction
news:
Over 250 students received their degrees at the 8th convocation of the School of Planning and Architecture (SPA) in Vijayawada, India.  P.R. Mehta, Chairman of the National Accreditation Board for Education and Training (NABET), urged graduates to embrace self-belief and conviction as they embark on their professional journeys.

Mehta emphasized the unique nature of the architecture and planning professions, noting their impact on the design of our living spaces.  He reminded the students that their degrees bring with them responsibility and accountability, opening up a world of creative possibilities in the field.

Amogh Kumar Gupta, Chairperson of the SPA Vijayawada Board of Governors, highlighted the pivotal role of architects and planners in modern society. He encouraged the new graduates to focus on creating projects that are environmentally conscious, cost-effective, sustainable, and relevant to their communities.

SPA Vijayawada Director, Ramesh Srikonda, presented a report showcasing the institute's achievements in the past academic year, including successful collaborations with leading national and international organizations.  The event concluded with the awarding of degrees to 253 students, including ten gold medals and ten best thesis awards in planning and architecture.

title: BJP Accuses Congress of Violating Election Code in Karnataka
news:
The Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) has accused the Congress government in Karnataka of violating the model code of conduct, which is currently in effect due to upcoming by-elections in three Assembly seats. 

The accusation stems from a government advertisement celebrating Valmiki Jayanti. BJP leader and Opposition leader R. Ashok claims the advertisement featuring both the Chief Minister and Deputy Chief Minister, along with a list of government achievements, violates the code. 

The BJP intends to bring the issue to the attention of the Election Commission. 

Meanwhile, Union Minister H.D. Kumaraswamy labelled the Congress government as "incompetent in governance, but surviving on publicity".  He criticized the government's focus on advertising while ignoring issues like flooding in Bengaluru and financial distress for farmers due to recent heavy rains.

title: Teacher Coordinators to Receive Training in Kerala
news:
**Thiruvananthapuram, Kerala:** The Institute of Parliamentary Affairs will be hosting a training program for teacher coordinators involved in youth and model parliament contests in schools and colleges. The program will take place on Friday at the Institute of Management in Government. 

The workshop will be inaugurated by MLA I.B. Satheesh. The training aims to equip educators with the necessary skills and knowledge to effectively manage and facilitate these parliamentary contests, fostering a deeper understanding of democratic processes among students.

title: Shiggaon Bypoll: A Race for Power and Prestige
news:
The upcoming by-election in Shiggaon Assembly constituency, previously held by former Chief Minister Basavaraj Bommai, is heating up. Both the ruling BJP and opposition Congress are vying for the seat, with numerous candidates vying for their party's ticket.

**BJP:**

* **Speculation surrounds Bommai's son, Bharat, as a potential candidate despite his father's denials.**  Bommai has confirmed former Minister Murugesh Nirani's intention to contest, but his outsider status may hurt his chances. 
* **Local candidates like Shrikanth Dundigoudra and Shashidhar Yeligar are also in the race.**  

**Congress:**

* **Despite a call for unity by KPCC president D.K. Shivakumar, the race for the ticket is fierce.**
* **The party has historically favoured minority candidates in Shiggaon, where the Muslim community is the second largest after the Panchamasalis.**
* **Former MLA Ajjam Peer Khadri and Yasir Khan Pathan are competing for the ticket.**
* **However, the Congress is also considering a Lingayat Panchamasali candidate this time, opening the door for leaders like former MLC Somanna Bevinamarad, Raju Kunnur, and R. Shankar.**
* **Vinod Asuti, who lost to Union Minister Pralhad Joshi in the Parliamentary election, is another potential candidate.**

Winning Shiggaon is a matter of prestige for the BJP, which has held the seat for over two decades. The party is determined to retain it, while the Congress is hoping to capitalize on any internal divisions within the BJP. The outcome of this by-election will be closely watched as a test of strength for both parties ahead of future elections.

title: India's Supreme Court Questions the Legality of Marital Rape Exception
news:
The Indian Supreme Court is currently examining the constitutionality of an exception in penal law that shields husbands from rape charges when the victim is their wife. This exception, present in both the Indian Penal Code (IPC) and the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS), has been challenged by petitioners who argue it violates women's fundamental right to bodily integrity, autonomy, and dignity. 

The court, in its initial hearing, raised serious questions about the rationale behind this exemption. Justice J.B. Pardiwala pointed out the legal inconsistency of punishing acts of confinement, intimidation, and assault preceding forced sexual intercourse, yet exempting the act itself when committed by a husband.

Chief Justice D.Y. Chandrachud highlighted the absurdity of allowing forced insertion of objects by strangers to be considered rape, but excluding the same act by a husband. He questioned the government's argument that criminalizing marital rape would threaten the institution of marriage, emphasizing that protecting women from rape within marriage does not equate to destroying the institution itself.

The petitioners, represented by senior advocate Karuna Nundy, argued that the exemption is discriminatory and violates constitutional values. They emphasized that marital status should not grant immunity from rape charges and that a woman's autonomy and dignity are paramount, even within marriage.  

The Supreme Court will continue its hearings, with the possibility of referring the case to a larger bench for a more comprehensive constitutional examination. This case is significant in its potential to redefine the legal framework surrounding consent and sexual violence within marriage, ultimately impacting the lives of countless women in India.

title: Ramli Ibrahim: Championing Odissi Dance Across Cultures
news:
Datuk Ramli Ibrahim, a Malaysian dancer and founder of the Sutra Dance Theatre, is widely recognized as a cultural ambassador for India in Malaysia. His dedication to the Odissi dance form has taken him across the globe, earning him accolades including the Sangeet Natak Akademi Award and the Padma Shri.

At 71, Ramli continues to inspire with his vibrant performances. His troupe's recent performance of "An Invitation to Odissi" at the Naman 2024 festival in Bengaluru received a standing ovation. Ramli's work pays tribute to the Guru Debaprasad Das school of Odissi, showcasing the dance's technical mastery and spiritual depth.

Ramli has a particular fondness for Kerala, having performed at the Nishagandhi Festival in Thiruvananthapuram. He expressed his interest in bringing his dance to Palakkad, intrigued by the region's traditional art form, Tholpavakkootthu.

Ramli's journey in the world of dance has been marked by cultural sensitivity and a desire to bridge cultural gaps. He believes in the power of art to transcend political and social boundaries, emphasizing the importance of understanding and appreciating diverse traditions.

"Modernity," he states, "can exist within the tradition; but you have to know the rules before you break them." Ramli encourages dancers to embrace both the traditional and contemporary aspects of Odissi, reminding them that the art form is a living entity that must evolve with the times.

His commitment to promoting Odissi dance, not just in Malaysia but across the world, has solidified Ramli Ibrahim's position as a leading figure in Indian classical dance.

title: NCLT Registrar Can't Decide Petition Maintainability: Karnataka High Court
news:
The Karnataka High Court ruled that the Registrar of the National Company Law Tribunal (NCLT) lacks the authority to determine the maintainability of petitions filed for initiating insolvency proceedings. 

The court emphasized that the Registrar's role is purely ministerial and procedural, focusing on receiving the petition. The court stressed that the Registrar's actions in receiving petitions under Sections 94 or 95 of the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code, 2016, do not involve any judicial function.

This decision stemmed from an appeal filed by Buoyant Technology Constellations Pvt. Ltd. challenging a single judge's ruling that had quashed the company's resolution process. The single judge argued that non-maintainable petitions should be rejected at the registration stage to prevent the automatic interim moratorium from coming into effect against the respondent.

However, the High Court disagreed, stating that the automatic moratorium provision does not grant the Registrar the power to assess petition maintainability.  The court emphasized that the NCLT's adjudicating authority, not the Registrar, is responsible for examining maintainability under Sections 96 to 100 of the code.

title: BJP Confident of Winning Wayanad By-Election
news:
The Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) has expressed confidence in fielding a strong candidate for the upcoming by-election in the Wayanad Lok Sabha constituency. M.T. Ramesh, BJP State general secretary, stated that the party will choose the right candidate to challenge the Congress party.

Ramesh criticized Congress' attempts to establish Wayanad as a reserved seat for the Nehru family, particularly targeting Rahul Gandhi's representation of the constituency despite his perceived lack of connection to the region. He highlighted that the residents of Wayanad have not seen any significant benefits from electing Gandhi as their MP, suggesting that voters are becoming increasingly aware of this.

Ramesh questioned why the Congress party couldn't identify a candidate outside the Gandhi family for Wayanad, implying a lack of leadership within the party. The BJP district president, Prashanth Malavayal, presided over the party meeting where these statements were made.

title: Rainfall Decreases in Andhra Pradesh as Depression Weakens
news:
After two days of heavy rain, Andhra Pradesh saw a decrease in rainfall on October 17th as the depression over the Bay of Bengal crossed the coast between Puducherry and Nellore early that morning. The India Meteorological Department (IMD) reported that the depression weakened into a well-marked low pressure area and remained over South Coastal Andhra Pradesh. 

The IMD further predicted that the low pressure area would move west-northwestwards and weaken further into a low pressure area within the next six hours. While a new upper air cyclonic circulation is anticipated to form over North Andaman Sea around October 20th, leading to the formation of a low pressure area over Central Bay of Bengal around October 22nd, this new system is expected to move northwestwards and intensify.

Visakhapatnam district recorded the highest rainfall with 60.75 mm, while Rayalaseema received less than 40 mm of rain on Wednesday. The A.P. State Disaster Management Authority has predicted light to moderate rainfall in North Coastal A.P. and the Godavari districts on October 18th.

title: COVID Commission Exposes ₹264 Crore Irregularities at Bengaluru's Kidwai Institute
news:
A commission investigating alleged irregularities at the Kidwai Memorial Institute of Oncology (KMIO) during the COVID-19 pandemic has uncovered discrepancies worth over ₹264 crore. The report, compiled by retired High Court judge John Michael D’Cunha, pinpoints issues in RTPCR testing, manpower recruitment, and equipment & drug procurement. 

The commission recommends issuing notices to the former Kidwai director, imposing penalties on suppliers, and recovering excess payments from various agencies.  The report highlights discrepancies in RTPCR testing, where a public-private partnership (PPP) with Bangalore Medical Systems (BMS) was falsely presented as an in-house lab, leading to inflated payments. 

Further irregularities were discovered in manpower recruitment and equipment procurement, including single-bid tenders and the lack of a tender acceptance committee. 

The commission emphasizes the need for a comprehensive investigation of all files related to these irregularities, calling for a dedicated officer to be appointed for this purpose.

title: Krishnagiri to Host Mega Job Fair on October 19th
news:
Krishnagiri district is set to host a mega job fair on October 19th, organized jointly by the district administration and the district employment and guidance cell. The event will take place at the Government Women's Arts College from 9 a.m. to 3 p.m.

Major companies from Krishnagiri and Hosur, including Ashok Leyland, Delta Electronics, and TVS, are expected to participate.  The fair is open to individuals who have completed at least Class 8, as well as graduates, postgraduates, and diploma holders. 

The district administration has clarified that individuals already registered with the employment office will not lose their position in the waiting order if they are recruited through the job fair. 

Collector K.M. Sarayu has encouraged the public to participate in the event.

title: Karnataka to Honor Maharshi Valmiki by Naming Schools and University After Him
news:
Karnataka Chief Minister Siddaramaiah has announced that all Scheduled Tribe residential schools and Raichur University will be renamed in honor of Maharshi Valmiki, the author of the Ramayana. 

The announcement was made at the Valmiki Jayanti program held on Thursday. Mr. Siddaramaiah praised Valmiki's journey from hunter to scholar, highlighting his emphasis on equality, justice, and equal opportunities for all.

He also emphasized that the concept of "Ram Rajya" depicted in the Ramayana represents a society characterized by fairness and equal opportunities. 

The Chief Minister further noted that two individuals from marginalized sections - Valmiki and Vyasa - authored the Ramayana and Mahabharata respectively. He urged marginalized communities to unite and speak out against injustice.

title: Puducherry Protesters Demand Justice for Assaulted Trader
news:
Puducherry witnessed tense scenes on Thursday as traders, led by Independent MLA G. Nehru, protested the assault of a shopkeeper and the alleged lack of proper medical care he received. 

The protest began with a march condemning the attack on Chandran, who was assaulted by three men seeking extortion money in his shop. The assailants fled with some goods after Chandran raised the alarm. 

Chandran, who sustained head and hand injuries, was initially taken to a government hospital but was allegedly sent home after receiving only first-aid. He was then directed to a primary health center that lacked scan facilities and was forced to return to the original hospital. 

The protesters, claiming Chandran was not provided adequate care, demanded the immediate arrest of the assailants. They staged a dharna at the hospital, then moved to the DGP's office, and finally to the Raj Nivas. 

Former Chief Minister V. Narayanasamy and Congress Legislature Party leader M. Vaithianathan also joined the protests, leading to negotiations with police and health officials.  The protest only dispersed after a doctor accompanied Chandran back to the hospital. 

The protesters ultimately filed a complaint with the Chief Minister, highlighting the need for swift action against the assailants and improved medical services for victims.

title: Madras HC Questions Defamation Case Against Tamil Nadu Speaker
news:
The Madras High Court is questioning the validity of a criminal defamation case filed against Tamil Nadu Legislative Assembly Speaker M. Appavu. Justice G. Jayachandran raised concerns about whether a speech delivered by the Speaker at a book release event in November 2023 actually defamed the All India Anna Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam (AIADMK). 

The judge is particularly interested in the standing of the complainant, AIADMK spokesperson R.M. Babu Murugavel, to file the case. The court cited previous Supreme Court and Madras High Court judgments stating that only the head of a party can file such complaints. The judge also questioned whether Murugavel's authorization from the party leadership was sufficient grounds to file a criminal defamation case.

The court also scrutinized the specific claims made by the complainant. While Murugavel accused the Speaker of stating that 40 AIADMK MLAs were poised to join the DMK following the death of former Chief Minister Jayalalithaa in 2016, the judge questioned whether the alleged statement actually defamed the AIADMK, considering the Speaker did not name any specific individuals. 

The court has granted the complainant's counsel until October 22 to answer the judge's questions regarding the case's validity.

title: Dutch Expert Advocates for Agricultural Transformation in Kerala
news:
Cees van Rij, Director of AgriGrade in the Netherlands, has urged for a strategic transformation in Kerala's agricultural practices. Drawing on the successful Dutch agricultural model, van Rij highlighted the potential for Kerala to benefit from community engagement and efficient supply chains, fostering a more sustainable and circular agricultural economy.

Speaking at the 18th International Co-operative Alliance Asia Pacific Research Conference in Kozhikode, van Rij outlined five key elements for agricultural transformation: 

1. **Sector Development:** Fostering collaboration between farmers, policymakers, and educational institutions to align sector needs with effective policies and practices.
2. **Innovation Adoption:** Embracing new technologies and techniques to enhance efficiency and sustainability.
3. **Investment Strategies:** Attracting and channeling investments towards key areas for agricultural growth. 
4. **Policy Collaboration:** Creating enabling policies that support and incentivize sustainable agricultural practices.
5. **Community Organisation:** Empowering local communities to play a more active role in the agricultural value chain.

The expert also suggested leveraging millet-based cropping systems as a sustainable solution to enhance food production resilience in the face of climate change. 

The discussion highlighted the challenges facing Indian agriculture, including low farmer incomes, persistent debt, and unfair market prices. Participants emphasized the need for structural reforms and innovative practices to revitalize Kerala's agricultural sector.

title: IISc Alumnus Funds Chair Professorships for Medical Research
news:
Former ISRO official and IISc alumnus S.R. Venkatramanan, along with his wife Usha Venkatramanan, have established two Chair Professorships at the upcoming postgraduate medical school at the Indian Institute of Science (IISc). This generous endowment, created in memory of Mr. Venkatramanan's parents, will support young faculty members at the Assistant Professor level, focusing on cutting-edge research in endocrinology and nephrology.

The "Usha and S.R. Venkatramanan Family Endowment" will provide continuous funding for these professorships, enabling them to conduct groundbreaking medical research. 

"We are extremely grateful to the Venkatramanan family for their generous contribution," stated G. Rangarajan, Director of IISc. "This endowment will encourage exceptional young researchers and bolster our efforts to establish a postgraduate medical school alongside the Bagchi-Parthasarathy hospital on campus." 

Mr. Venkatramanan, who holds an Electrical Technology degree and a Physical Engineering Master's from IISc, believes in the Institute's ability to attract top researchers and translate discoveries into practical solutions. He highlighted the importance of finding a cure for Type-1 diabetes and developing stem cell solutions for kidney failure, citing the significant impact these conditions have on individuals' lives.

The contribution was facilitated through the IISc Foundation, a non-profit organization based in the USA that supports research and infrastructure development at the Institute.

title: DHAN Foundation Marks International Day for Eradication of Poverty
news:
On October 17th, 2024, DHAN Foundation commemorated the International Day for the Eradication of Poverty (IDEP) with a focus on empowering the poor through community-driven initiatives. The event brought together community members and field staff from Madurai, Theni, Dindigul, and Ramanathapuram districts to discuss issues surrounding poverty eradication. 

This year’s IDEP theme, “Ending Social and Institutional Maltreatment Acting Together for Just, Peaceful, and Inclusive Societies,” resonated deeply with the Foundation's ongoing work. Executive Director M.P. Vasimalai emphasized the need for the poor to organize themselves into community institutions to access development resources. Addressing deep-rooted issues within families was also highlighted as crucial to overcoming poverty. 

The role of Self Help Groups (SHGs) in poverty eradication and women empowerment was discussed by CEO of Kalanjiam Foundation A. Umarani. She noted the emergence of thousands of women leaders through these groups, driving social change in their communities. 

CEO of Vayalagam Foundation V. Venkatesan focused on the water conservation efforts of farmers, which contribute to the Movement Out of Poverty. These efforts ensure food and livelihood security while promoting agro-biodiversity and sustainable development. 

K. Rajalakshmi, CFO of Kalanjiam Foundation, spoke about how the DHAN Foundation’s development programs, through social capital and stakeholder collaboration, were already addressing social and institutional maltreatment. 

Members of Kalanjiam and Vayalagam shared personal stories about how their association with the institutions helped them address poverty, gain access to financial inclusion, credit, health services, education, sustainable agriculture, and non-farm livelihoods. To mark the occasion, a book documenting these case stories was released, followed by a pledge to continue facilitating pathways out of poverty.

title: Nawaz Sharif Calls for Improved India-Pakistan Ties
news:
Former Pakistani Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif has urged India and Pakistan to move beyond past conflicts and improve relations. Speaking to Indian media in Lahore, Sharif emphasized the importance of fostering a different future, particularly in addressing shared challenges like climate change and energy shortages. 

He expressed hope that External Affairs Minister S. Jaishankar's recent visit to Pakistan for the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation (SCO) meeting marks a "beginning" and will lead to further "opening" of relations. Sharif also stated his desire for India and Pakistan to play cricket matches on each other's home grounds.

Sharif placed blame for the current state of strained relations on former Pakistani Prime Minister Imran Khan's personal statements about Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi, which he believes could "destroy good relations between any two countries."

While declining to address contentious past issues like the Pathankot terror attack, Sharif advocated for easing visa restrictions between the two countries, suggesting that India and Pakistan should treat each other as potential markets and collaborate on trade, industry, and energy. 

He recalled the positive steps taken during his time in office, including the Lahore Declaration and his meeting with Modi in 2015. Sharif acknowledged the "long-pause" in formal talks since then, but expressed his hope for a renewed dialogue and improved relations. 

It remains unclear whether Sharif's statements reflect the official stance of the current Pakistani government or indicate a shift in the country's overall approach to relations with India.

title: Union Minister Pushes for Collaborative Innovation in Science & Technology
news:
Union Minister of State for Science and Technology, Jitendra Singh, has urged for a collaborative approach to innovation in India, encompassing academia, research institutions, start-ups and industry. During the inauguration of the CSIR-National Institute for Interdisciplinary Science and Technology's (NIIST) year-long golden jubilee celebrations in Thiruvananthapuram, Dr. Singh emphasized the importance of public-private partnerships (PPPs) to foster innovation. 

He highlighted the government's commitment to supporting collaborations across various sectors, particularly in space, where a surge in start-ups, now exceeding 300, has been attributed to government policies promoting private sector involvement. Dr. Singh expressed confidence that similar integrated approaches could be applied to other fields, including healthcare and traditional practices like Ayurveda. 

Further underscoring the government's dedication to research, he highlighted the newly established Anusandhan National Research Foundation, designed to enhance research viability both domestically and globally. Dr. Singh also encouraged CSIR-NIIST to develop a 25-year roadmap focused on nurturing young talent, aligning with the "Mission Viksit Bharat 2047" initiative aimed at transforming India into a developed nation. 

The event also witnessed the laying of the foundation stone for the Centre of Excellence in Ayurveda Research on the NIIST campus, alongside the inauguration of the Centre of Excellence in Performance Chemicals and Sustainable Polymers.  Memorandums of Understanding were exchanged for technology transfers between CSIR-NIIST and various entities, including the Sree Chitra Tirunal Institute for Medical Sciences and Technology (SCTIMST), Vikram Sarabhai Space Centre (VSSC), and several private companies.

title: Food Fortification: A Key to Nutritional Security
news:
A national seminar held in Thiruvananthapuram, India, focused on innovative food fortification strategies to combat malnutrition. Organized by the United Nations World Food Programme (UNWFP) and the College of Agriculture, the event highlighted the crucial role of fortification in addressing global food security challenges.

The seminar, titled "Innovative Approaches to Global Nutritional Security through Food Fortification," brought together experts and researchers to discuss cutting-edge strategies for enriching food with essential nutrients. Key speakers emphasized the need for science-driven interventions in agriculture to tackle nutritional deficiencies.

Dr. Nozomi Hashimoto, Deputy Country Director of the UNWFP for India, announced the establishment of rice fortification units at the College of Agriculture, further emphasizing the program's commitment to promoting this approach. 

The seminar featured scientific presentations on advancements in fortification technology and visual displays showcasing innovative methods. Participants discussed the importance of ensuring nutrient-rich diets and explored collaborative efforts between academia, research institutions, and industry to implement food fortification on a larger scale. 

The event concluded with a consensus that strategic food fortification, particularly of staple foods like rice, holds immense promise in combating nutrient deficiencies and promoting nutritional security for all.

title: Attingal Students Beautify Walls with Waste Management Messages
news:
Students in Attingal, Kerala, are taking a creative approach to promoting responsible waste management. As part of the "Malinya Muktham Navakeralam" campaign, they've been cleaning public walls and painting them with graffiti and messages about waste reduction.

The project, dubbed "Manassu Maattam, Mathilukal Bhangiyakkam" (Mind Speaks, Walls Bloom), has seen students from various government schools transforming walls in the town center.  Previously covered in old posters and advertisements, the walls now feature colorful artwork encouraging environmentally conscious practices. 

Attingal municipality chairperson S. Kumari praised the students' efforts, stating that they are effectively spreading the message of responsible waste management to the community. She noted that the initiative has involved students from the Government Girls Higher Secondary School, the Government High School, Avanavancheri, and other local institutions.  

In addition to wall art, Student Police Cadets from Avanavancheri have also created seating using discarded plastic bottles at the municipality office.

title: Kumaraswamy Willing to Discuss KIOCL and Kudremukh with Karnataka Government
news:
Former Karnataka Chief Minister and Union Minister for Heavy Industries and Steel, H.D. Kumaraswamy, has expressed his willingness to engage in discussions with the State government regarding KIOCL (Kudremukh Iron Ore Company Limited) and HMT. He accuses the state government of "lying" about their handling of these public sector undertakings. 

Kumaraswamy claims that over 300-400 KIOCL employees are currently unemployed due to the state government's inaction. He also alleges that the state government, despite emphasizing the need for local employment opportunities, is not cooperating with KIOCL. 

He has pledged to hold a meeting with Chief Minister Siddaramaiah and Forest Minister Eshwar Khandre, armed with documents, to address these concerns.  Kumaraswamy asserts that he will take responsibility for any mistakes made by KIOCL, as the head of the relevant department. 

This statement comes in response to accusations made by the Karnataka government regarding KIOCL's financial obligations. The state government claims that KIOCL owes over ₹1,400 crore in dues related to the Devadari mining project, contradicting Kumaraswamy's statement that KIOCL has already paid ₹500 crore to the Forest Department.

title: Karnataka's Caste Census: Bypolls Could Stall Crucial Decision
news:
The Karnataka government's decision to discuss the caste census report in its upcoming Cabinet meeting on October 24th could be thrown into disarray due to upcoming bypolls in three constituencies. 

Caste lobbies opposed to the census, including the Akhila Bharatha Veerashaiva Mahasabha and the Vokkaliga Sangha, are actively lobbying against the report. Fears of political backlash during the bypolls are leading to speculation that the government might postpone the discussion.

The Mahasabha, which has already expressed concerns about the accuracy of the census data, is holding meetings with community leaders and elected officials. The Vokkaliga Sangha, representing another significant caste group, has also opposed the census, citing concerns about the potential consequences of the report.

The caste census was conducted in 2017 during the first tenure of Chief Minister Siddaramaiah. The report, submitted earlier this year, has sparked controversy due to its potential impact on the state's political landscape and the sensitive nature of caste politics in Karnataka. 

The government's decision to address the caste census amidst looming bypolls will be closely watched, as it reflects the delicate balance between political expediency and social justice in the state.

title: Telangana CM Challenges Opposition to Live on Musi Riverbed to Prove Rejuvenation Project Claims
news:
Telangana Chief Minister A. Revanth Reddy has challenged leaders of the BRS and BJP to live in houses on the Musi riverbed for three months to prove their claims that the area is habitable. This bold move comes after accusations that the opposition parties are exploiting the Musi riverfront development project for political gains.

Reddy insists that the conditions around the Musi riverbed are not suitable for living due to pollution and other problems. He has even offered to pay rent and provide basic amenities for the leaders who accept his challenge.

The project aims to improve living conditions for residents who are currently suffering from the river’s pollution. The Chief Minister accuses the opposition of using false propaganda to criticize the project, without offering any constructive suggestions for improving the rehabilitation packages offered to residents.

Reddy has invited the opposition to participate in a special legislative session to discuss the project and address their concerns. He has also proposed that the session include Parliament members, allowing them to contribute their suggestions. 

The Chief Minister emphasizes the government’s commitment to consulting with stakeholders and emphasizes that the project will only proceed after winning over the affected families.

title: BJP MP Accuses Opposition of Threatening Waqf Bill Panel Chief
news:
BJP MP Tejasvi Surya has accused Opposition members of threatening the Chairman of the Joint Committee examining the Waqf (Amendment) Bill, Jagdambika Pal, during a recent meeting. In a letter to Lok Sabha Speaker Om Birla, Surya demanded disciplinary action against the Opposition MPs for their "unruly behaviour" and "physical threats" towards both Pal and a witness, former Karnataka State Minorities Commission chairman Anwar Manippadi.

The conflict stems from Manippadi's presentation to the committee, which included a 2012 report alleging "large-scale encroachment or sale of approximately 2,000 acres of Waqf land" to private entities. This report implicated several Congress leaders, including party president Mallikarjun Kharge.

The Opposition claims Manippadi's presentation was politically motivated and demanded Pal halt it. They walked out of the meeting, accusing the committee of operating in a "partisan and politically motivated environment." Surya, however, maintains the report was tabled in the Karnataka Legislative Assembly and authenticated by the then Lokayuka in 2016. He alleges the Opposition's actions were a blatant disregard for parliamentary decorum.

title: Mahe Ayurveda Interns Stage Indefinite Strike for Stipend Hike
news:
Interns at the Rajiv Gandhi Ayurveda Medical College and Hospital (RGAMCH) in Mahe have launched an indefinite strike, demanding a significant increase in their stipend. The interns currently receive ₹5,000 per month and are seeking a raise to ₹20,000.

Their demand is based on an assurance from Chief Minister N. Rangasamy in November 2022 that their stipend would be brought on par with interns at the Institute of Growth and Medical Sciences (IGMCRI). Despite repeated pleas to the Chief Minister and Education Minister, the promised stipend hike has not been implemented.

Following a symbolic strike in February, the interns have escalated their protest to an indefinite strike. They demand immediate issuance of a government order regarding the stipend increase and allocation of sufficient funds in the upcoming revised budget in December.

title: MVA Reaches Consensus on 260 Seats in Maharashtra
news:
The Maha Vikas Aghadi (MVA), a coalition of the Shiv Sena (UBT), Congress, and NCP (SP), has reportedly reached a consensus on 260 out of the 288 assembly seats for the upcoming Maharashtra elections. 

NCP (SP) supremo Sharad Pawar, while not directly involved in the seat-sharing discussions, confirmed that an agreement has been reached for approximately 200 seats. He downplayed concerns that the Congress's recent defeat in the Haryana assembly elections would negatively impact the MVA's prospects in Maharashtra, emphasizing that the BJP retained power in Haryana and that the MVA is analyzing the results.

The MVA is set to challenge the ruling Mahayuti alliance, comprising Eknath Shinde's Shiv Sena, BJP, and Ajit Pawar-led NCP. The Maharashtra assembly elections are scheduled for November 20, with vote counting on November 23.

title: Hyderabad Man Loses ₹8.65 Lakh in Investment Scam
news:
A 22-year-old man from Hyderabad fell victim to a trading and investment scam, losing ₹8.65 lakh. The incident occurred after the victim received WhatsApp messages from two different numbers offering trading tips. He initially used his Grow account for trading before switching to an "INX account" called Total Securities LTD, which promised integrated access to global stock exchanges. 

The victim deposited funds into the account throughout September 2024 but was denied access when he attempted to withdraw his ₹8.65 lakh. He subsequently filed a cybercrime complaint. 

Hyderabad cybercrime police have warned citizens to use only Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI) approved apps and financial advisors for investment. They cautioned against fake investment groups on platforms like Telegram, WhatsApp, X, Instagram, and Facebook.

title: Thiruvananthapuram Observatory Captures Rare Comet C/2023 A3
news:
The Thiruvananthapuram Astronomical Observatory, run by Kerala University, has captured stunning images of the bright comet C/2023 A3 (Tsuchinshan–ATLAS). The comet, originating from the Oort cloud, was first spotted in January 2023 and became visible to the naked eye after passing its closest point to the sun in September. 

While the comet was at its closest to Earth on October 12, inclement weather in Thiruvananthapuram hindered observations. However, the observatory successfully captured images on Wednesday, October 16, marking a significant achievement for the region's observational astronomy. 

Comet C/2023 A3 is currently traversing the Orion constellation and is expected to remain visible for the next three days. As it moves further away from the sun, its brightness will decrease, making this a fleeting opportunity for skywatchers. While it has been described as the brightest comet in over a decade, it is not expected to reach the iconic brilliance of Comet Hale-Bopp, which dazzled observers in 1997.

The observatory welcomes the public to view the comet during its open hours, from 6 pm onwards, weather permitting.

title: Infosys Profits Rise, Dividend Declared: Good News for Narayana Murthy
news:
Infosys, India's second-largest IT services exporter, has reported a nearly 5% increase in its net profit for the second quarter of the fiscal year (July-September 2024). The company also announced an interim dividend of Rs 21 per share, with a record date of October 29 and payout date of November 8. 

The company's net profit reached Rs 6,506 crore, a 4.7% rise compared to the same period last year and a 2.2% increase from the previous quarter. This growth was driven by a broad-based recovery in demand, particularly from the financial services sector. 

Infosys has also revised its revenue guidance for the full fiscal year, now expecting a growth of 3.75% to 4.5% in constant currency. This upward revision is attributed to the ramp-up of mega deals and the company's increasing focus on generative AI solutions.

While Infosys added 2,500 employees in the September quarter, marking an end to six consecutive quarters of staff reduction, the company maintained its EBIT margin guidance for the fiscal year at 20% to 22%.

The positive news is a boost for Infosys co-founder Narayana Murthy, who has been vocal about the company's performance in recent years.

title: Enhanced Women's Participation Sought in Governance
news:
A national conference held in Tirupati, India, emphasized the need for increased women's participation in governance at all levels. Speakers, including C. Narayanaswamy, Chairman of the 5th State Finance Commission, Government of Karnataka, advocated for a 33% reservation for women in all government positions.  

The conference, organized by the Academy of Grassroots Studies and Research of India (AGRASRI), highlighted the importance of women's voices in shaping policies and fostering balanced development. Participants discussed the challenges women face in entering politics and urged political parties to allocate a greater number of seats to women candidates. 

The event also saw the presentation of several awards recognizing individuals and institutions for their contributions to good governance at the local level.

title: Rift Rumors Surface as Chandy Oommen Skips UDF Candidate's Visit to Puthuppally
news:
Speculation of a rift within the Congress party has emerged following the absence of Chandy Oommen, MLA from Puthuppally, during a visit by Rahul Mamkoottathil, the UDF candidate in the upcoming Palakkad byelection, to Puthuppally on Thursday. 

Mamkoottathil visited the tomb of Oommen Chandy at St. George Orthodox Church, accompanied by senior Congress leaders K.C. Joseph, Thiruvanchoor Radhakrishnan, and P.C. Vishnunath. Oommen, who was reportedly in Delhi attending to constituency matters, was absent.

While both Oommen and Mamkoottathil downplayed the rumors, citing scheduling conflicts and ongoing communication, party insiders suggest a different story. Mamkoottathil had initially planned to visit Puthuppally the day after his candidacy announcement but delayed his trip in hopes of Oommen's presence. Sources claim that Oommen expressed dissatisfaction over the change in schedule, potentially leading to Mamkoottathil's decision to proceed without him. 

This incident follows Oommen's removal from the Youth Congress national outreach cell in July, reportedly due to a report submitted by Mamkoottathil to party leadership. While the absence of Oommen during Mamkoottathil's visit is being attributed to logistical issues, the incident has sparked whispers of a potential rift within the Congress, adding an interesting dimension to the upcoming byelection.

title: Heavy Rain Disrupts Goa Road Travel
news:
Heavy rains in Belagavi and along the Karnataka-Goa border have caused significant traffic jams on the Ramnagar-Anmod highway, one of the primary routes connecting Belagavi to Goa. The congestion began on Wednesday and continued into Thursday, causing inconvenience for travelers. 

National Highway Authorities of India (NHAI) officials have initiated minor repair works on the affected stretches of the road. Movement of heavy vehicles resumed by Thursday evening after the repairs commenced. 

Project Director Bhuvanesh Kumar visited the site to assess the situation. He reported that the road became slushy in certain areas, particularly near Astoli, leading to the halting of heavy vehicles. 

Repair efforts are ongoing and are expected to continue throughout the night. The NHAI has identified further stretches requiring repairs.

title: Curfew-like Situation in Gurla, Andhra Pradesh Amidst Diarrhoea Outbreak
news:
A curfew-like situation prevails in Gurla, a mandal headquarters in Vizianagaram district of Andhra Pradesh, following an outbreak of diarrhoea.  The outbreak has caused widespread fear among residents, leading to a near-total shutdown of the town with most shops closed and residents staying indoors. 

While the majority of residents remain confined to their homes, government officials are actively working to curb the spread of the disease.  They have implemented a special sanitation drive, ensuring thorough cleaning of every street, including Raja Veedhi, Chakali Veedhi, Golla Veedhi, and BC Colony. Water supply through pipelines has been halted and residents are advised against consuming water from borewells. Water is currently being supplied to households through tankers.

A comprehensive survey has been conducted to identify new cases, with fortunately, no new cases reported.  The 40 individuals currently being treated at a special medical camp are showing signs of improvement. 

The Chief Minister's Office is closely monitoring the situation, and officials are taking every precaution to ensure the safety and well-being of the community.

title: Indian Society of Cardiology's National Conference Kicks Off in Alappuzha
news:
The 19th National Conference of the Indian Society of Cardiology (ISCCON 2024) will convene in Alappuzha, Kerala, from October 18 to 20.  This gathering of over 500 cardiologists, healthcare professionals, researchers, and fellows will focus on the latest advancements in cardiovascular medicine. 

The conference, held at the Uday Backwater Resort, promises in-depth discussions on all aspects of heart disease management, from prevention to rehabilitation.  Attendees will gain insights into cutting-edge research and therapies, covering topics such as non-invasive cardiac imaging, coronary thrombectomy, valvular heart disease, and electrophysiology.

ISCCON 2024 will officially commence on Friday, with the inaugural ceremony scheduled for Saturday, featuring Dr. Rajendra Gokhroo, president of the Indian Society of Cardiology, as the keynote speaker.  

The conference will feature a wide array of scientific sessions spread over three days, covering topics such as primary PCI (angioplasty), stent placement, coronary imaging, physiological assessments, echocardiography, adult cardiology, bifurcation PCI, electrophysiology, intravascular ultrasound, structural heart disease interventions, and chronic total occlusion.  Experts will also lead sessions on hypertension management, lipid management, and new therapies for triglycerides.

The concluding day will focus on the future of cardiology, with presentations on metal-less PCI, advancements in heart failure treatment, genetic screening in cardiology, precision medicine, and future developments in coronary stents.  

The event will also feature a medical and technology exhibition showcasing the latest innovations in the field.

title: Chennai to See Light to Moderate Rain Through the Weekend
news:
Chennai residents can expect light to moderate rainfall through the weekend, according to the Regional Meteorological Centre (RMC). While a depression that crossed the coast near Chennai on Thursday has weakened, isolated heavy rain is forecast for Friday in the north-interior districts. 

The RMC predicts an increase in rainfall activity from October 20, with moderate intensity rain expected for three days.  However, the city is unlikely to experience extreme weather conditions. 

The depression, which formed over the Bay of Bengal, brought down chances of extreme rainfall over northern Tamil Nadu after it weakened. 

Meanwhile, a new upper air cyclonic circulation is predicted to form over the north Andaman Sea on October 20, potentially leading to the development of a low-pressure area over the central Bay of Bengal around October 22. The RMC is monitoring the weather system to assess its impact on the state. 

The recent rainfall is part of a larger wet spell associated with the remnants of the depression. October’s rainfall is already 82% above the normal average of 7.7 cm.

title: Calicut University to Hold Graduation Ceremony for PG Students
news:
The Calicut University Syndicate has approved a proposal to hold a graduation ceremony for postgraduate (PG) students graduating in 2024. This decision was made at a Syndicate meeting held on Thursday, October 17th, 2024.

The meeting also saw the approval of renaming the School of Distance Education to the Centre for Distance and Online Education, with the statute being amended accordingly. A sub-committee has been formed to revise the guidelines for the inspection of autonomous colleges.

The decision to hold a graduation ceremony for PG students is a positive development, recognizing the achievements of these students and providing them with a formal platform to celebrate their success.

title: Political Intervention Key to Backward Class Progress, Says Mahadevappa
news:
Mysuru district in charge Minister H.C. Mahadevappa emphasized the crucial role of political interventions in addressing the challenges faced by backward classes, including the Valmiki community. While acknowledging the economic difficulties faced by many Valmiki community members, particularly their shift away from agriculture, Mahadevappa highlighted the government's commitment to their comprehensive development. 

During the Jayanti celebrations honoring poet and saint Valmiki, Mahadevappa praised the Ramayana as a reflection of Indian culture and values. He also commended the state government's allocation of ₹9,000 crore in the current budget for the collective progress of backward classes. 

The Minister's remarks underscore the government's focus on addressing historical inequities and promoting the social and economic well-being of marginalized communities. The allocation of significant funds indicates a tangible effort to support their advancement and inclusion.

title: CPI Fields Veteran Sathyan Mokeri for Wayanad By-election
news:
The Communist Party of India (CPI) has selected Sathyan Mokeri as their candidate for the upcoming Wayanad Lok Sabha by-election. Mokeri, a veteran politician, will represent the ruling Left Democratic Front (LDF) in the race. 

The CPI State Secretary, Binoy Viswam, expressed confidence in Mokeri's ability to connect with voters, citing his legislative experience and leadership within the farmer's association. Mokeri served as the representative for the Nadapuram constituency in the Assembly for three terms, between 1987 and 2001. He also held positions within the All India Kisan Sabha, including State Committee member and Vice-President.

The by-election was triggered by Congress leader Rahul Gandhi's decision to retain his Raebareli seat in Uttar Pradesh. The Congress has nominated Priyanka Gandhi Vadra to contest the Wayanad seat. This by-election is particularly noteworthy as Annie Raja, representing the CPI, lost to Rahul Gandhi by a significant margin in the Lok Sabha elections earlier this year.

title: Madurai Protest Demands Release of Fishermen Imprisoned in Bahrain
news:
A protest was held in Madurai on Thursday, urging the Indian government to secure the release of 28 fishermen currently imprisoned in Bahrain. The demonstration, organized by the Tamil Fishermen Federation (Tamil Meenavar Kootamaipu), involved family members of the imprisoned fishermen, political groups, and other concerned citizens.

The fishermen were arrested while engaging in deep-sea fishing near Iranian waters and are being held in judicial custody in Bahrain. The protest organizers, including Federation President A. Rajini, demanded immediate action from both the Central and State governments to bring the fishermen home. 

Concerns were also raised about the ongoing harassment of Indian fishermen by Sri Lankan authorities. Ms. Rajini highlighted recent incidents where fishermen from Rameswaram faced arrest, heavy fines, and even the nationalization of their boats. She emphasized the urgent need for a political solution between India and Sri Lanka to address these issues. 

The protesters attempted to disrupt train services by attempting to enter Madurai Railway Junction, but were prevented by police.  This protest underscores the growing frustration of Indian fishermen who feel their livelihoods are under threat, and calls for the government to prioritize their safety and well-being.

title: Consortium to Revitalize Musi River in Hyderabad
news:
A consortium of renowned companies has been selected to prepare a detailed project report (DPR) and explore funding options for the Musi River rejuvenation project in Hyderabad. The consortium, comprising Meinhardt, RIOS, Cushman & Wakefield, ZHA, and SOM, will receive ₹141 crore for their six-and-a-half-year commitment.

The Telangana government has entrusted the consortium with the responsibility of developing a comprehensive DPR within 18 months. Following this, the consortium will work for another five years to identify potential investors and funding avenues for the project. The government is exploring a public-private partnership model and other alternative funding mechanisms.

The Chief Minister, A. Revanth Reddy, refuted criticisms surrounding the project, stating that the government's intention is to revitalize the Musi River, a unique natural resource flowing through the city's heart. He also questioned the opposition's claims of a ₹1.5 lakh crore investment, comparing it to the allegedly fraudulent Kaleshwaram project of the previous government.

title: Free Legal Aid Helpline Launched in Krishnagiri, Tamil Nadu
news:
